text:
You'd need to think about it in the way funds are handled. Users funds are invested in multiple defi protocols, not just one, so never the full amount of user funds are under absolute risk.

The good thing about our methods is diversity, it is some sort of insurance on its own, we do not hold more than a certain % of user funds in a single protocol, so let's say any protocol fails or gets hacked like the example you ask about, then only a % of user funds are truly ever lost on these very unlikely events. What's left to do or consider, depending on the extent and nature of damage, insurance might come into play

Now on the topic of insurance, we're currently insured by our wallet provider, BitGo, under the following terms:
For more information related to insurance, please check the following:

text:
You'd need to think about it in the way funds are handled. Users funds are invested in multiple defi protocols, not just one, so never the full amount of user funds are under absolute risk.

The good thing about our methods is diversity, it is some sort of insurance on its own, we do not hold more than a certain % of user funds in a single protocol, so let's say any protocol fails or gets hacked like the example you ask about, then only a % of user funds are truly ever lost on these very unlikely events. What's left to do or consider, depending on the extent and nature of damage, insurance might come into play

Now on the topic of insurance, we're currently insured by our wallet provider, BitGo, under the following terms:
For more information related to insurance, please check the following:

messages.text: No, its not really true. Check yhis pictogram.

I don't think it's trading really, but there are liquidity pools for example which return much more than 8% APR. So they will invest in various think that range from fixed return, no risk, to very high return, high risk, and from that they can be sure of your 8% APR.But that might go up or down if things are going well or not so well.
We do not trade with user funds, cronty
That is always good advice!
We invest user funds in tried and tested DeFi protocols, as Piotr pointed out above

Also, wherever your fiat is kept, unless its under your mattress, its being invested in various things which are higher or lower risk. Your pension invests in funds that it expects to profit from. So does your bank. Even the church does!
Ahh, okay. sorry I misunderstood.

The difference with crypto is higher risk and higher returns. You get that nice fixed APR with Yield because its a really nice return and fixed, but maybe not spectacular by crypto standards. It's definitely a lot less stressful.
Let's say the yield website goes down. My coins would be gone too isn't it?
How do you mean the yield website go down?
Wow

The coins are not stored on my physical wallet.
If there is no website, no access to my coins isn't it?

Let me ask you a simple counter question:

"What would happen if Binance suddenly go down?" you can ask this of every platform, and I don't know if there's a satisfactory answer to it, at least from an internal point of view it feels like a loaded / dishonest question in the sense that we're here working to deliver the best possible product, and "what happens if it goes down", well for it to go down everyone I work with would need to suddenly stop doing their work and that just will not happen. So, yeah, in my opinion is just not a possibility

They actually are, we have a system of HSMs to secure the funds. We're soon moving from using BitGo as a wallet provider to a custom solution that will allow us to physically hold the coins in a secure location

I've asked on April about ETA of Android App, and was told "6-8 weeks" or (Q2)

What the reason for the huge delay?
That's what we've been told 26 weeks ago...

V2 is many, many things - from the BTC fund, to full cycle swapping, to in-house wallets, to a whole new improved user experience, to cross chain capability, to fiat on ramps, to so, so much more. And it's coming as fast as we can get it to you while ensuring that every element is 100% solid and of the quality that you would and should expect from us
We're also planning to start onboarding testers from the community very soon

We never had or could afford such delays.
What about ETA, the R&D team are working without ETAs?

You might be serious, but excuse me, it seems like you are not working by any reasonable r&d framework.
All known frameworks (SCRUM / Agile /  Kanban / and more...) have ETAs.
It seems like the dev team is in a mess.

Having an ETA doesn‚Äôt mean there will be a stable deliverable at that moment. Besides that there could be reasons that are not related to the development team, thinking of management or wanting to package multiple development projects in one release, etc

I don't suspect it be an exit scam, but looking  as a new user I wouldn't invest my money in such project.
Congrats team.
You have access to the best APY in CEFI since the beginning , don‚Äôt complain because V2 is longer than expected .
I prefer security and APY rather than rushing a buggy v2

messages.text: I am mention it because there is a contradiction between what is stated on FAQs and the front page of the side that says that funds are insured. As a wealth management company I believe you need to provide assurances that the capital is safe from malicious actions.

text:
Yes, and as Giorgio mentions, you need to think about it in the way funds are handled. Users funds are invested in multiple defi protocols, so never the full amount of user funds are under absolute risk.

This diversity, it is some sort of insurance on its own, we do not hold more than a certain % of user funds in a single protocol, so let's say any protocol fails or gets hacked like the example you ask about, then only a % of user funds are truly ever lost on these very unlikely events. What's left to do or consider, depending on the extent and nature of damage, insurance might come into play

Now on the topic of insurance, we're currently insured by our wallet provider, BitGo, under the following terms:
For more information related to insurance, please check the following:

I said black swan events where all of the things are gone. It could happen, but it is unlikely, and we don't want it to happen, ever. Diversification is one of the steps we took to prevent it so that no one is going to lose money. Another step is to chip in some our profits to cover if the unlikely things happen. 

You asked me if a screenshot of my message could benefit you, well I don't know. What we know is that we do everything to bring a safety net for everyone in the platform. And we won't stop doing it.
Yes, it's planned in the future.

For some clarity, it is always recommended to read through the FAQ‚Äôs and other documents that we publish on our website. For crypto insurance in general, cold or custodial wallets provide protection against a narrow range of risk vectors, typically hacks, loss of keys or malicious actions of the platform employees. In practice, once a user of any platform puts their funds to work, the capital is normally at risk.

To mitigate potential losses with any passive income asset class or traditional fund management, diversification is employed to provide capital protection. This is applied through multiple verticals focusing on highly liquid, market neutral strategies and in-kind asset-based allocations. 

The technology solution we deploy utilises a ring-fenced data infrastructure that includes data centres, hardware security modules, chain dedicated nodes and a proprietary portfolio management system supported by robust, industry standard best practises adopted by global portfolio risk managers.

In our upcoming Q3 report we will be explaining in more detail how we manage risk, our current insurance reserves and other new protections coming during Q4.

‚Ä¢ Prediction Markets (Gnosis and Augur)
‚Ä¢ Collateralized Lending (Aave)

‚Ä¢ Derivatives (Synthetix and Opyn)

‚Ä¢ Permissionless Aggregators (Zapper)

messages.text: Hi guys quick question, let's say I deposit my money in Yield. How is Yield generating money so that it can pay me back interest ?
Through the use of tried and tested protocols, mainly DeFi!

And by making use of the economics of scale and these protocols, you don't specifically need to trust us, and even though we're a centralized plattform the funds that we manage are easy to redeem / withdraw if at any point you lose trust on the project, the only exception being the recent BTC fund which has some limitations in this regard
Can you provide me some concrete examples ?
They wont disclose that my good sir
It's hard for me to trust it if I don't know what it's done with my money

We can give a few examples of platforms or protocols we may make use of, but we cannot disclose specifically how much or if any of these protocols is actually being used at any given time as YIELD App's portfolio management team is very dynamic in this regard

Here's a few examples of what we refer to when talking about Tried and tested protocols, particularly DeFi solutions currently fall into a few prominent categories. These include:

‚Ä¢ Prediction Markets (Gnosis and Augur)
‚Ä¢ Collateralized Lending (Aave)
‚Ä¢ Collateralized Stable Assets (DAI)
‚Ä¢ Automated Market Makers (Uniswap, Balancer)
‚Ä¢ Derivatives (Synthetix and Opyn)
‚Ä¢ Smart Contract Insurance (Nexus Mutual)
‚Ä¢ Permissionless Aggregators (Zapper)
‚Ä¢ Non-Fungible Tokens (NFTs) are also now used to generate value from digital collectibles, gaming tokens, digital art, and other goods and services in a permissionless manner.

Specific protocols and how much is allocated to each is propietary, so that's why there's no more specific data on this matter, hope you understand

text:
There is a more detailed explanation to our portfolio management strategy in our Q3 report, along with many, many more infos !
Read more about it here :

Our core objective of providing high yielding passive income returns in a secure environment has not changed, rather it continues to improve. These disclosures and increased transparency will continue as we move forward. With respect to V2, the objective is to strengthen and enhance our core mission and as such the platform will be released when we are confident that the these same objectives are met. text: Justin,  at this point, it's worse to not have an approx. ETA, than an actual ETA regarding V2. You fail to have open

communication regarding V2 and it's launch nor it's technical progress. I've asked several times to test out an alpha/beta or whatever version platform you are working on. Since there hasn't been any reply to these requests, other than images of screens. 
The community deserves clear answers regarding V2. If the answers are -soon / we don't want to give an eta- or the same of the same we have been hearing for a long while now, many of us who have been patient (including myself) can not responsibly accept the risk while waiting in the dark. We have been patient so far because we expected v2 to be launched by now. It's NOT launched and we still don't know when it will be launched. It's time you took our concerns serious. I'm sure I don't need to explain that there are other venues who DO communicate transparent and do take complaints serious. 

This is not about rates / your hiring / your growth of users etc. Many of us need to know at what stage your development is. What are stages are left and be able to have a reasonable idea of when v2 will be launched. 

I remember your one of your responses the first time around was that you didn't want to open source the code because of competitors. This is also not about that. 

You know exactly what it is that many of us are referring to and talking around the issue and not addressing it directly for such a long time is making many of us nervous. To put it simply, the risk/reward ratio is off because of the lack of transparent communication regarding v2.

messages.text:
You make it sound like things aren't getting done until V2 gets launched. V2 is just one of the milestones, with lot's of things inside. I would understand if Yield didn't have the product already working, but this isn't the case.

Would changing the version in the current app to 2.0.0 suffice? Because most of the things aren't going to be finished so fast, the debit card for example. If it only gets released end of next year, will people keep asking for the full V2 version until then?

Your clearly unhappy with my answers. I would be happy to have a private call with you in the coming days to understand your concerns and your expectations above and beyond the underlying business objective that I‚Äôve articulated. Please feel free to DM me to set this up.
